39326.re: courses 5A/L or 6A/L; concurrent enrollment in course 6B required.

39327.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 6B. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
39327.re: courses 5A/L or 6A/L; concurrent enrollment in course 6B required.

39328.desc: The physics of mechanics, wave motion, temperature, pressure, and fluids. A lecture and discussion course that provides a basic foundation of physics for students whose major interest is in biology or another science.
39328.re: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 7L is required. High school algebra, geometry, and trigonometry are recommended.

39329.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 7A. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
39329.re: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 7A is required.

39330.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 7A. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
39330.re: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 7A is required.

39331.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 7A. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
39331.re: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 7A is required.

39332.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 7A. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
39332.re: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 7A is required.

39333.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 7A. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
39333.re: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 7A is required.

39337.desc: Topics in quantum physics, including angular momentum and spin, the Pauli exclusion principle, and quantum statistics. Applications in multi-electron atoms, molecules, solid state physics, and nuclear and particle physics.
39337.re: course 14 or Mathematics 23B; course 101A; 5A/L, 5B/M, and 5C/N or 6A/L, 6B/M, and 6C/N.

39339.desc: Maxwell's equations, electrostatics, magnetostatics, induction, electromagnetic waves, physical optics, and circuit theory.

39341.desc: Consequences of the first and second laws of thermodynamics, elementary statistical mechanics, thermodynamics of irreversible processes.

39343.desc: Demonstration of phenomena of classical and modern physics. Development of a familiarity with experimental methods. Special experimental projects may be undertaken by students in this laboratory.

39344.desc: Individual experimental investigations of basic phenomena in atomic, nuclear, and solid state physics. May be repeated for credit.

39345.desc: Interatomic forces and crystal structure, diffraction, lattice vibrations, free electron model, energy bands, semiconductor theory and devices, optical properties, magnetism, magnetic resonance, superconductivity.
39345.re: courses 112 and 139A; students with equivalent coursework may contact instructor for permission to enroll.

39346.desc: Seminars to help students explore their theses topics and plan, organize, and develop their theses. Refining the thesis outline; preparing draft sections, preparing a written progress report; delivering an oral progress report. Students must complete 5 credits in the 195 series to satisfy the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.

39419.desc: Mathematic introduction; fundamental postulates; time evolution operator, including the Heisenberg and Schrodinger pictures; simple harmonic oscillator and coherent states; one-dimensional scattering theory, including S-matrix resonant phenomena; two-state systems, including magnetic resonance; symmetries, including rotation group, spin, and the Wigner-Eckart theorem; rotationally invariant problems, including the hydrogen atom; gauge invariance, including Landau levels; introduction to path integral.
39419.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students only, except by permission of instructor.

39420.desc: Path integral approach to quantum field theory. Theory of renormalization and the renormalization group, introduction to gauge theories and spontaneously broken field theories. Applications to the standard model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions.
39420.re: course 217. Enrollment restricted to graduate students only, except by permission of instructor.

39421.desc: Intensive research seminar on cosmology and related topics in astrophysics: nature of dark matter; origin of cosmological inhomogeneties and other initial conditions of the big bang; origin and evolution of galaxies and large scale structure in the universe.
39421.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students only, except by permission of instructor.

39422.desc: Seminar on the current literature of elementary particle physics, ranging from strong and weak interaction phenomenology to Higgs physics, supersymmetry, and superstring theory. Students may present their own research results. May be repeated for credit.
39422.re: course 218; enrollment restricted to graduate students.

39423.desc: Weekly seminar attended by faculty and graduate students. Directed at all physics graduate students who have not taken and passed the qualifying examination for the Ph.D. program.
39423.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students only, except by permission of instructor.

39780.desc: Sequential to course 1A, completes first-year accelerated instruction. Intensive instruction in elementary Portuguese, emphasizing oral proficiency as well as reading and writing skills. Taken together, courses 1A and 1B are equivalent to first-year instruction.

39781.desc: Sequential to course 60A, completes first-year accelerated instruction of Portuguese for speakers of Spanish and other Romance languages. This sequence is designed for students with an equivalent of four quarters of college level study of Spanish, French, Italian, or Catalan or for native speakers of these Romance languages (including heritage speakers of Portuguese). Prepares students in all language skills.

39786.desc: Students are introduced to the different folk dances of the Philippine Islands. Folk dances of the tribal mountain region, of the Spanish Era in the Philippines (Maria Clara Era), and dances of the regional and rural countryside are emphasized. May be repeated for credit.

39787.desc: Writers, directors, and technical workers in areas of TV and film discuss current work, paths that led to their creative endeavors, and constraints of working in the industry. Students research aspects of film and TV professional work. Cannot be repeated for credit.

39788.desc: Organized in small teams, participants engage with students from public elementary classrooms to develop fully-staged group performance projects by end of term. Students are guided by instructor's models of teaching techniques, designed to stimulate the imagination, and by diverse readings.

39800.desc: A program of independent study arranged between a group of students and a faculty instructor.

39820.desc: Introduces prospective majors to the scientific study of behavior and mental processes and also provides an overview for non-majors. Emphasizes social, cognitive, developmental, and personality psychology and their interrelations.

39832.desc: An introduction to elementary statistical principles and techniques relevant to psychological research. Topics covered include basic parametric and nonparametric statistics, analysis of variance, and simple factorial designs. This course is prerequisite to course 181.
39832.re: course 1, and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3 or Mathematics 3 or 11A or satisfactory placement score on math placement exam or CEEB Advanced Placement Calculus AB exam.

39837.desc: Psychological development from birth to adolescence, with primary emphasis on infancy and childhood. A broad introduction to the nature of change during childhood and adolescence and to theories of development.
39837.re: course 1. Enrollment restricted to pre-psychology majors.

39842.desc: A study of human sexuality emphasizing its psychological aspects. Sexual development, sexual orientations, biological influences, sexual attitudes and behavior, gender and gender roles, sex therapy, sexual coercion and abuse, sexually transmitted diseases, and the development of sexual relationships.

39846.desc: Serves as an in-depth introduction to the field of clinical psychology. Covers issues of clinical assessment, interviewing, testing, and a range of therapeutic modalities.
39846.re: courses 3, and 60 or 65; course 170 is recommended as preparation.

39848.desc: A seminar course with focus on theories of moral development from the psychoanalytic, social learning, cognitive-developmental, and humanistic perspectives. Students confront and discuss moral dilemmas from the four perspectives, working toward their own individual theories of pro-social behavior. Course satisfies seminar requirement. Satisfies senior comprehensive requirement. Prerequisite(s): essay required on a moral issue or dilemma relevant to the student's life.

39849.desc: Students lead discussion groups and provide one-to-one tutoring for course 1. Admission requires essay describing interest in becoming a course assistant, copies of psychology evaluations, and a letter of recommendation from a psychology faculty member; completion of some upper-division psychology courses prior to enrollment in this course. Enrollment restricted to psychology majors.

39893.desc: Provides students with intensive experience conducting current research in developmental psychology. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

39894.desc: Provides students with intensive experience conducting current research in cognitive psychology. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

39895.desc: Provides students with intensive experience conducting current research in social psychology. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

40228.desc: A proseminar reviewing current topics in cognitive psychology, designed to introduce new graduate students to the field.
40228.re: Enrollment restricted to psychology graduate students.

40229.desc: Seminar to study, critique, and develop research in perception and cognition, including topics in psychobiology, psycholinguistics, and memory. May be repeated for credit.
40229.re: Enrollment restricted to psychology graduate students.

40230.desc: Seminar to study, critique, and develop research in social psychology. May be repeated for credit.
40230.re: Enrollment restricted to psychology graduate students.

40231.desc: Seminar to study, critique, and develop research in developmental psychology. May be repeated for credit.
40231.re: Enrollment restricted to psychology graduate students.

40232.desc: An examination of contemporary theory and research on socioemotional and personality development across the lifespan.

40233.desc: Tailored to graduate students' interests among topics involving research and scholarship in sociocultural approaches to development, methods for research design, data collection, coding, and analysis, and preparing and reviewing grant proposals and journal manuscripts. Multiple-term course; students receive 6 credits in the third quarter of attendance; the performance evaluation and grade submitted for the final quarter applies to all three quarters. May be repeated for credit.

40452.desc: Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing. Recitation and laboratory.

40453.desc: Second-year courses designed to improve functional competence in speaking, listening, reading, and writing by activating basic grammar covered in introductory courses. Grammatical explanations and exercises supplemented with short readings and films.

40476.desc: A survey of selected feature articles in the current national science magazines, with attention to strategy, level of complexity, explanation technique, and style. Writing assignments include a publishable feature article.
40476.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students formally accepted into the writing track of the Science Communication Program.

40477.desc: Theory and practice of writing and editing articles on scientific, medical, environmental, and technological subjects for newspapers, magazines, and special publications directed at non-technical readers. May be repeated for credit.
40477.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students formally accepted into the writing track of the Science Communication Program.

40493.desc: A 20- to 25-hour per week internship in a Washington, D.C. government, non-profit, or private institution, consistent with availability and student's interests. In addition, weekly attendance at required seminar which stresses institutional analysis, development of bibliographic material using Washington resources, and participant-observer skills. Required for participants in the UCDC program. Enrollment restricted to students participating in the UCDC Program.

40494.desc: A 20- to 25-hour per week internship in a Washington, D.C. government, non-profit, or private institution, consistent with availability and student's interests. In addition, weekly attendance at required seminar which stresses institutional analysis, development of bibliographic material using Washington resources, and participant-observer skills. Required for participants in the UCDC program. Enrollment restricted to students participating in the UCDC Program.

40496.desc: Exploration of nature, structure, and functionings of American society. Explores the following: social institutions and economic structure; the successes, failures, and intractabilities of institutions; general and distinctive features of American society; specific problems such as race, sex, and other inequalities; urban-rural differences. Fulfills lower-division major requirement.

40501.desc: Introduction to information technology and communication networks using the Internet to reduce global inequality and bridge the "digital divide." Prepares students enrolled in the Global Information Internship Program to construct web pages and write grant proposals for community and non-governmental organizations. Course 186 recommended but not required. May be repeated for credit.

40508.desc: Explores the history of the use and abuse of consciousness-altering substances like alcohol and other drugs. Social-psychological theories of addiction are reviewed in tandem with political-economic analyses to identify the social conditions under which the cultural practices involved in drug use come to be defined as public problems. An introductory sociology course is recommended prior to taking this course.

40729.desc: Intensive survey of major tendencies in modern social thought, including functionalism, symbolic interactionism, ethnomethodology, critical theory, structuralism, phenomenology, neo-Marxism, and feminist theory.
40729.re: Enrollment restricted to graduate students in sociology and by permission number.

40812.desc: Speaking, listening comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals. Taught entirely in Spanish; conversational fluency is encouraged through classroom practice and conversation groups, and is supplemented by language laboratory work. Classes are held three days a week; students complete the conversation group work independently of the classroom sessions.

40813.desc: Speaking, listening comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals. Taught entirely in Spanish; conversational fluency is encouraged through classroom practice and conversation groups, and is supplemented by language laboratory work. Classes are held three days a week; students complete the conversation group work independently of the classroom sessions.

40814.desc: Speaking, listening comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals. Taught entirely in Spanish; conversational fluency is encouraged through classroom practice and conversation groups, and is supplemented by language laboratory work. Classes are held three days a week; students complete the conversation group work independently of the classroom sessions.
40814.re: course 1 or Spanish Placement Examination score of 20.

40815.desc: Speaking, listening comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals. Taught entirely in Spanish; conversational fluency is encouraged through classroom practice and conversation groups, and is supplemented by language laboratory work. Classes are held three days a week; students complete the conversation group work independently of the classroom sessions.
40815.re: course 1 or Spanish Placement Examination score of 20.

40819.re: course 2, 2X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 30.

40822.re: course 2, 2X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 30.

40823.desc: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various sociopolitical and cultural issues in the Spanish speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
40823.re: course 3, 3T, 3X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 40.

40824.desc: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various sociopolitical and cultural issues in the Spanish speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
40824.re: course 3, 3T, 3X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 40.

40825.desc: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various sociopolitical and cultural issues in the Spanish speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
40825.re: course 3, 3T, 3X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 40.

40826.desc: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various socio-political and cultural issues in the Spanish speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
40826.re: course 4, 4X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 50.

40827.desc: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various socio-political and cultural issues in the Spanish speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
40827.re: course 4, 4X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 50.

40829.desc: Increases oral and written proficiency using authentic reading materials which focus on such topics as social class, ethnicity, education, religion, economic, and political developments in the Spanish-speaking world.
40829.re: course 5, 5M, 5X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 60.

40830.desc: Increases oral and written proficiency using authentic reading materials which focus on such topics as social class, ethnicity, education, religion, economic, and political developments in the Spanish-speaking world.
40830.re: course 5, 5M, 5X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 60.

40862.desc: Comprehensive review of the subjunctive, the passive voice, different uses of "se," and other nuances of the language. Intensive practice in understanding specialized readings, presentation/discussion of major ideas, vocabulary expansion, and writing essays on topics discussed.
40862.re: course 61 or placement exam. Students who have not taken Spanish for Spanish Speakers 61 need to speak with an instructor in the Spanish for Spanish Speakers Program.

40863.desc: Comprehensive review of the subjunctive, the passive voice, different uses of "se," and other nuances of the language. Intensive practice in understanding specialized readings, presentation/discussion of major ideas, vocabulary expansion, and writing essays on topics discussed.
40863.re: course 61 or placement exam. Students who have not taken Spanish for Spanish Speakers 61 need to speak with an instructor in the Spanish for Spanish Speakers Program.

40880.desc: A program of independent study arranged between a group of students and a faculty instructor. Enrollment restricted to members of Stevenson College. Enrollment limited to 12.

40883.desc: A program of independent study arranged between a group of students and a faculty instructor. Course designed for members of Stevenson College. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. Enrollment limited to 10. May be repeated for credit.

40897.desc: Individual projects carried out under the supervision of a Stevenson faculty member. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

40901.desc: Individual projects carried out under the supervision of a Stevenson faculty member. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

40907.desc: Intensive instruction in developing the dancer's physical instrument, combined with basic movement theory. May be repeated for credit with consent of instructor. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.

40908.desc: Work is on various aspects of theatrical production, including scenery, lighting, costumes, sound, stage management, and video documentation. Satisfies the department's technical experience requirement. May be repeated for credit.

40912.desc: Continuing concentrated work on basic acting skills and textual analysis through scene study. May be repeated for credit with consent of instructor. Prerequisite(s): admission by audition at first class meeting. See department office for more information. Course 21 recommended as preparation. May be repeated for credit.

40913.desc: Studies in theater, taken in connection with participation in a Theater Arts Department sponsored production. Enrollment is limited to those persons chosen to take part in a particular production. Admission by audition; audition schedule to be announced at first class meeting. May be repeated for credit.

40914.desc: A process-oriented investigation of specific playwrights or theatrical styles consisting of work which may culminate in a final production. Admission by audition at first class meeting; see department office for more information. May be repeated for credit.

40915.desc: An examination of the theories of acting and directing from the 19th century to our own time, starting with the classic theater and concentrating on the 20th-century debate centered in Stanislavski and Brecht, Grotowski, and Robert Wilson.
40915.re: course 60A, 60B, and 60 C. This course must be taken prior to student's senior year; required for course 185.

40916.desc: A required seminar for majors involving readings and discussions of important texts in dance, design, and drama.

41076.desc: Individual field study in the vicinity of the campus under the direct supervision of a faculty sponsor. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

41086.desc: Individual field study in the vicinity of the campus under the direct supervision of a faculty sponsor. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

41096.desc: The senior thesis/project which satisfies the major requirement. Course is for independent research and writing. Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements; students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

41106.desc: Provides for individual study program off campus for which faculty supervision is not in person. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

41116.desc: Provides for individual study program off campus for which faculty supervision is not in person. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

41135.desc: Individual directed study for upper-division undergraduates. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

41145.desc: Independent study and research under faculty supervision. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

41146.desc: A basic composition course, which helps students find specific, practical ways of improving every aspect of their writing, through a broadly based consideration of the nature of language from a diversity of perspectives.
41146.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing requirement.

41205.desc: Explores the dynamics of written language: its relationships to speech, thought, and culture; its uses in different personal, academic, professional, and public contexts; its abuses in jargon and propaganda. Course work includes extensive practice in different kinds of writing. Enrollment restricted to students who have not passed the Entry Level Writing Requirement. Open to others by permission of instructor.

Course work includes extensive practice in different kinds of writing. Enrollment restricted to students who have not passed the Entry Level Writing Requirement. Open to others by permission of instructor.

Course work includes extensive practice in different kinds of writing. Enrollment restricted to students who have not passed the Entry Level Writing Requirement. Open to others by permission of instructor.
